Termite Control
In coastal areas of the US, drywood termites are very common. Drywood termite swarmers differ from subterranean termites in appearance primarily in color. Drywood termite swarmers are red with blackish wings and are easily confused with the carpenter ant.
Just because you have not seen termites swarm does not necessarily mean you do not have a problem, there are other indicators. Subterranean termites create mud tunnels to travel to and from the structure, as normal exposure to daylight will kill them. The mud tube helps to protect the worker termites from predators such as ants, and also provides them with humidity. The mud tube is the path that the termites travel from to get their food. In the early stages, the tubes are fairly small as seen in the photographs. With time they will be made several inches wide to accomodate more feeding and larger numbers. If you believe you have a termite infestation, contact a professional immediately! Structural damage can be done in relatively a small amount of time if left untreated.
Be sure to read your termite policy very closely. Usually, owners are very surprised when they find out too late that there is not a "damage guarantee" in the policy. Without this, you will be responsible for any damages that the termites have caused when they are found (even if the home has been treated or is monitored by an outside company). Obviously the coverage plans which provide full damage protection and repair cost considerably more. If you live in a termite prone area (see chart below) you may be very sorry that you chose the cheaper policy when it is too late!
